customData.content: 44-year-old asymptomatic nulliparous woman presented with a palpable pelvic mass. Physical examination revealed an enlarged uterus of about 10- to 12-week size, which was mobile, firm in consistency, with no uterine or forniceal tenderness, and mild swelling in the right pubic area.

HPI.summary: 44-year-old asymptomatic nulliparous woman presented with a palpable pelvic mass.

customData.content: Gynecological sonography on January 30, 2010, identified an anterior wall uterine leiomyoma, measuring 112×94×108 mm, accompanied by ascites measuring 65×42 mm and a 20×14 mm mass.

imaging.finding: anterior wall uterine leiomyoma, measuring 112×94×108 mm, accompanied by ascites measuring 65×42 mm and a 20×14 mm mass
anterior wall uterine leiomyoma, measuring 112×94×108 mm

customData.content: Laparotomic myomectomy performed on February 17, 2020, with incidental discovery of a pelvic tumor. Pelvic tumor described as a cauliflower-like lesion disseminated across the right pelvic wall, cul-de-sac, anterior uterine surface, bladder, and colon.

imaging.finding: cauliflower-like lesion disseminated across the right pelvic wall, cul-de-sac, anterior uterine surface, bladder, and colon

customData.content: Biopsy of the sigmoid colon serosa (0.8 cm sample) showed proliferative mesothelial cells without significant atypia or necrosis. Post-myomectomy CT scan revealed seeding in the lower pelvis, characterized by multiple small, heterogeneous, enhancing nodules on the peritoneum and a prominent soft-tissue mass in the right adnexa. Postoperative pelvic CT scan performed on February 26th, 2020.

imaging.finding: multiple small, heterogeneous, enhancing nodules on the peritoneum and a prominent soft-tissue mass in the right adnexa

procedures.name: Biopsy
procedures.outcome: proliferative mesothelial cells without significant atypia or necrosis

customData.content: CT scan revealed moderate ascites and nonspecific peritoneal thickening, with small enhancing nodules on the peritoneal membrane and soft-tissue thickening in the right adnexa. Histopathology identified bland mesothelial cells without invasion, and immunohistochemistry showed no significant staining loss. Differential diagnosis included well-differentiated papillary mesothelioma, epithelioid peritoneal mesothelioma, and florid mesothelial hyperplasia; well-differentiated papillary mesothelioma was highly suspected.

imaging.finding: moderate ascites and nonspecific peritoneal thickening, with small enhancing nodules on the peritoneal membrane and soft-tissue thickening in the right adnexa
imaging.impression: moderate ascites and nonspecific peritoneal thickening, with small enhancing nodules on the peritoneal membrane and soft-tissue thickening in the right adnexa

procedures.name: Histopathology
procedures.outcome: bland mesothelial cells without invasion, and immunohistochemistry showed no significant staining loss

data.content: Patient went from presentation with palpable pelvic mass to gynecological sonography revealing anterior wall uterine leiomyoma, ascites, and a mass.
Patient underwent laparotomic myomectomy, leading to the incidental discovery of a pelvic tumor.

Following myomectomy and incidental discovery of pelvic tumor, a biopsy of the sigmoid colon serosa was performed, revealing proliferative mesothelial cells without significant atypia or necrosis. A post-myomectomy CT scan revealed seeding in the lower pelvis.

Following biopsy and CT scan, another CT scan revealed moderate ascites and nonspecific peritoneal thickening. Histopathology identified bland mesothelial cells. Differential diagnosis included well-differentiated papillary mesothelioma, epithelioid peritoneal mesothelioma, and florid mesothelial hyperplasia; well-differentiated papillary mesothelioma was highly suspected.
